issue.title: rpc, doc: getpeerinfo updates
issue.body: Various updates and fixups, mostly targeting v24. Please refer to the commit messages for details.

rename.to: netinfo: fix relaytxes doc, display 3 relaytxes states

events.body: @MarcoFalke @shaavan thanks for taking a look! Addressed your feedback, improved the getpeerinfo#relaytxes help, and added explicitly handling the new (v24.0) relaytxes 3rd state of "not available" in -netinfo.

`relaytxes` is set based on the value of `m_relay_txes` if `fStateStats` is **true**; otherwise, `relaytxes` is unavailable.

[net.cpp 203]( https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/src/rpc/net.cpp#L203)

```cpp
if (fStateStats) {
            obj.pushKV("relaytxes", statestats.m_relay_txs);
        }
```

And `fStateStats` is equal to false when either Node or peer is **nullptr**:

[net_processing.cpp 1555](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/src/net_processing.cpp#L1555)

```cpp
if (state == nullptr)
            return false;
```

[net_processing.cpp 1566](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/src/net_processing.cpp#L1566)

```cpp
if (peer == nullptr) return false;
```

The value of `relaytxes` depends on the value of statestats.m_relay_txs.

And the value of `statestats.m_relay_txs` can be false in two cases:

if `m_tx_relay→m_relay_txs` is **false**.

[net_processing.cpp 1580](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/src/net_processing.cpp#L1580)

```cpp
if (auto tx_relay = peer->GetTxRelay(); tx_relay != nullptr) {
        stats.m_relay_txs = WITH_LOCK(tx_relay->m_bloom_filter_mutex, return tx_relay->m_relay_txs);
```

or if `m_tx_relay` is a **nullptr**.

[net_processing.cpp 1583](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/src/net_processing.cpp#L1583)

```cpp
else {
        stats.m_relay_txs = false;
```

And according to the comment on `m_tx_relay`, it will be a **nullptr** when we are not relaying transactions to this peer

[net_processing.cpp 398](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/src/net_processing.cpp#L398)

```cpp
/** Transaction relay data. Will be a nullptr if we're not relaying
     *  transactions with this peer (e.g., if it's a block-relay-only peer or
     *  the peer has sent us fRelay=false with bloom filters disabled). */
    std::unique_ptr<TxRelay> m_tx_relay GUARDED_BY(m_tx_relay_mutex);
```

So as far as I understood, there are four possible states:

1. Node asked to relay, and we will relay txs to this node `(m_tx_relay` ≠ **nullptr** and `m_tx_relay` → m_relay_txs = **True**)
2. Node asked not to relay `(m_tx_relay` ≠ **nullptr** and `m_tx_relay→m_relay_txs` = **False**)
3. Node is not yet setup (`peer` == **nullptr**, irrespective of values of `m_tx_relay` and `m_relay_txs`)
4. Node is setup but we can’t relay to it (`m_tx_relay` = **nullptr**)

The first three states are properly represented by the PR using "", "*", "." repectively. However, I think there is a need to address the 4th state as well in which we can't relay transactions to the peer.

>     4. Node is setup but we can’t relay to it (`m_tx_relay` = **nullptr**)
> 
> The first three states are properly represented by the PR using "", "*", "." repectively. However, I think there is a need to address the 4th state as well in which we can't relay transactions to the peer.

@shaavan thanks for looking. Running `git grep -B4 "stats.m_relay_txs = false;"`, in the 4th case you describe `PeerManagerImpl::GetNodeStateStats()` returns `m_relay_txs` as false (and so getpeerinfo#relaytxes is false). This is one of the 3 states (true, false, not available) returned by that field and handled here.

utACK d51dbbc697adeac2563727e27f49b98bcc319914

I was able to verify the three states in the code and the lack of documentation that this PR fixes. Couldn't we cover this case where relaytxes is not available in a functional test? I confess that I could test manually this field by running it, and could check true/false states but it has been a little difficult to test manually and get a n/a.

If relaytxes is omitted ONLY if it hasn't been setup yet, we should just include it as `false` IMO.

(But if it could be during peer *destruction*, that might not be correct)

@luke-jr I tend to agree; nevertheless see https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/26109#discussion_r973091972 for the rationale, which was considered compelling enough to make getpeerinfo#relaytxes optional after being always present since the API field was introduced in 08843ed99843078acb10eecda2045d5f0f1c2b4f. Edit: I've added the link to the pull description.

Thank you @brunoerg! @MarcoFalke @shaavan mind re-reviewing? @w0xlt @dunxen @kristapsk @1440000bytes @Zero-1729 @0xB10C @jarolrod you have reviewed these kind of changes in the past, if you don't mind having a look.
Updated to take feedback by @Zero-1729, ACKs and re-ACKs welcome :)

issue.title: [24.x] backport rpc: Require NodeStateStats object in getpeerinfo

events.body:
tACK 7c733bd25e024a23e75fb1015e1c394df88df2d0

Tested on macOS v13.0 (22A380)

I can confirm this patch splits the displayed `relaytxes` states into three (true, false, n/a due to pending setup), updates the help docs, and release notes.

- - -

issue.title: Webhook server and framework for bot features with ACK tracker
issue.body:
This PR adds a new summary comment that appears at the top of every (new) pull request.
It contains an ACK tracker that works as follows:

When a user comments or adds a review (edits and deletions are detected) or the PR author pushes to the PR, the bot will rescan every comment and review for ACKs.
An `ACK` can be a `(N)ACK`, `Concept (N)ACK`, `Approach (N)ACK`, `Code Review (N)ACK`, and `Stale ACK`.

For a raw `ACK` to be valid, a commit hash that matches the PR's head is expected (`ACK <commit sha>`).
If the commit hash no longer matches the PR's head, it goes stale. 
Concept ACKs, Code Review ACKs, Approach ACKs, and NACKs don't require a commit hash but one can be specified so that if the commit referenced no longer matches the head, the 'ACK' will be removed from the tracker automatically.
The case of the comment does not matter and takes into account ACK aliases such as re-ACK, reACK, utACK, crACK, etc.

Specifically, this PR:
- Adds a webhook server for receiving GitHub events of a repository
- Adds a framework for adding features to the Bot, with different event types
- Adds the summary comment feature

There is currently no secret-based webhook authentication but it can be done if this PR is Concept ACKed.

<details>
<summary>Summary comment</summary>

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22493292/199021732-8b5c1c6e-6636-4d3a-9659-00b6ba3ea8cc.png)

</details>

<details>
<summary>ACK example</summary>

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22493292/199023038-bc4c58ee-9f82-4e1c-b858-289f6def4791.png)

</details>

<details>
<summary>Stale ACK</summary>

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22493292/199024155-a54de3ac-94df-4c64-a75f-96afd1364954.png)


</details>

Links in the `Reviewers` cell will automatically scroll down to the specific review.

issue.title: rpc: skip getpeerinfo for a peer without CNodeStateStats
issue.body:
The objects `CNode`, `CNodeState` and `Peer` store different info about a peer - `InitializeNode()` and `FinalizeNode()` make sure that for the duration of a connection, we should always have one of each for a peer.

Therefore, there is no situation in which, as part of getpeerinfo RPC,  `GetNodeStateStats()` (which requires a `CNodeState` and a `Peer` entry for a `NodeId` to succeed)  could fail for a legitimate reason while the peer is connected - this can only happen if there is a race condition between peer disconnection and the `getpeerinfo` processing (see also a more detailed description of this in https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/26457#pullrequestreview-1181641835). 

But in this case I think it's better to just not include the newly disconnected peer in the response instead of returning just parts of its data.

An earlier version of this PR also made the affected `CNodeStateStats` fields non-optional (see https://github.com/mzumsande/bitcoin/commit/5f900e27d0e5ceaa3b800a2eb5a8e8ff6bccad3b). Since this conflicts with #25923 and should be a separate discussion, I removed that commit from this PR.

events.body: Closing for now in favor of #26516.
Re-opening after reading https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/26457#issuecomment-1316597000, pending reviewer feedback here and on #26516 (the latter has the benefit of not changing user space).

issue.title: rpc: Always return getpeerinfo "relaytxes" field
issue.body:
with its pre-existing v23 default value of false, as it is intermittently absent during peer disconnection -- see https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/26457#pullrequestreview-1181641835.  Credit to Martin Zumsande for finding this. 

This allows dropping the patch in #25176 here, and, if backported to v24, provides API continuity as relaytxes was always present in getpeerinfo since it was introduced in 2015.

Also fix -netinfo relaytxes doc to address https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/26109#discussion_r995502563.

Co-authored-by: Martin Zumsande <mzumsande@gmail.com>

issue.title: cli: include local ("unroutable") peers in -netinfo table
issue.body:
Closes https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/26579

The `-netinfo` dashboard did not list peers that were connected via "unroutable" networks. This included local peers including local-network peers. Personally, I run one bitcoind instance on my network that is used by other services like Wasabi Wallet and LND running on other machines. 

This PR adds an "npr" (not publicly routable) column to the table of networks (ipv4, ipv6, onion, etc) so that every connection to the node is listed, and the totals are accurate as they relate to max inbound and max outbound limits.

Example connecting in regtest mode to one local and one remote peer:

```
Bitcoin Core client v24.99.0-151ce099ea8f-dirty regtest - server 70016/Satoshi:24.99.0/

<->   type   net  mping   ping send recv  txn  blk  hb addrp addrl  age id address         version
 in          npr      0      0   90   90                              1  1 127.0.0.1:59180 70016/Satoshi:24.99.0/
out manual  ipv4     63     63   84   84         3                    3  0 143.244.175.41  70016/Satoshi:24.0.1/
                     ms     ms  sec  sec  min  min                  min

         ipv4    ipv6     npr   total   block  manual
in          0       0       1       1
out         1       0       0       1       0       1
total       1       0       1       2

Local addresses: n/a


```

events.body:
What are the next steps here?

> pending reviewer feedback here and on https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/26516 (the latter has the benefit of not changing user space).

The reviewer feedback in #26516 seems to be that the change is either incorrect, or maybe needs better justification.

The [reviewer feedback in this PR](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/26328#discussion_r1024197861) seems to be that the tri-state change is unnecessary, because the third state to display `(N/A)`, will never be used, as it's impossible to have missing values during connection setup, as described in the docs added here.

I think how RPC returns that a value is missing, (with optional, or a magic value, or some extended logic) is orthogonal to cli netinfo changes. However, it would be beneficial to first figure out the RPC interface and then adjust the cli and gui code to that.

issue.title: rpc: remove optional from fStateStats fields
issue.body: These are no-longer optional after #26515, so remove the documentation, and no-op `fStateStats` checks.

rename.from: netinfo: fix relaytxes doc, display 3 relaytxes states

events.message:
doc: fix up -netinfo relaytxes help

Co-authored-by: "MarcoFalke <*~=`'#}+{/-|&$^_@721217.xyz>"

events.body: Simplified to just the fixup to https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/26109#discussion_r995502563 found by @MarcoFalke.
Code Review ACK 0f5fc4f656d0990802ab552c0e620f49e785fed4

I think my misunderstanding came from the fact that it is unclear if `version.relaytxs` or `getpeerinfo.relaytxs` was meant, see https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/26109/files#r1067201660

In any case https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/commit/0f5fc4f656d0990802ab552c0e620f49e785fed4 lgtm
This has been merged.

> I think my misunderstanding came from the fact that it is unclear if `version.relaytxs` or `getpeerinfo.relaytxs` was meant, see [#26109 (files)](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/26109/files#r1067201660)
> 
> In any case [0f5fc4f](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/commit/0f5fc4f656d0990802ab552c0e620f49e785fed4) lgtm

I almost added `s/relaytxes/getpeerinfo \"relaytxes\" field/` here yesterday. Might sneak it next time I touch the file.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -642,7 +642,7 @@ class NetinfoRequestHandler : public BaseRequestHandler
         "  send     Time since last message sent to the peer, in seconds\n"
         "  recv     Time since last message received from the peer, in seconds\n"
         "  txn      Time since last novel transaction received from the peer and accepted into our mempool, in minutes\n"
-        "           \"*\" - whether we relay transactions to this peer (relaytxes is false)\n"
+        "           \"*\" - we do not relay transactions to this peer (relaytxes is false or not available)\n"
comments.body: if it is not available it will default to true, no?

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -642,7 +642,7 @@ class NetinfoRequestHandler : public BaseRequestHandler
         "  send     Time since last message sent to the peer, in seconds\n"
         "  recv     Time since last message received from the peer, in seconds\n"
         "  txn      Time since last novel transaction received from the peer and accepted into our mempool, in minutes\n"
-        "           \"*\" - whether we relay transactions to this peer (relaytxes is false)\n"
+        "           \"*\" - we do not relay transactions to this peer (relaytxes is false or not available)\n"
comments.body:
@MarcoFalke 
Yes, I was able to verify your point

On line https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/src/bitcoin-cli.cpp#L542, the `"*"` or `""` is selected based on bool value of `is_tx_relay`.

```cpp
peer.last_trxn ? ToString((time_now - peer.last_trxn) / 60) : peer.is_tx_relay ? "" : "*",
```

and,
on line https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/src/bitcoin-cli.cpp#L481, `is_tx_relay` defaults to **True** when `relaytxes` is **Null**

```cpp
const bool is_tx_relay{peer["relaytxes"].isNull() ? true : peer["relaytxes"].get_bool()};
```

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -642,7 +642,7 @@ class NetinfoRequestHandler : public BaseRequestHandler
         "  send     Time since last message sent to the peer, in seconds\n"
         "  recv     Time since last message received from the peer, in seconds\n"
         "  txn      Time since last novel transaction received from the peer and accepted into our mempool, in minutes\n"
-        "           \"*\" - whether we relay transactions to this peer (relaytxes is false)\n"
+        "           \"*\" - we do not relay transactions to this peer (relaytxes is false or not available)\n"
comments.body: Thanks, done, and added displaying the new "not available" state distinctly from the "true but no last tx time" state.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -642,7 +643,8 @@ class NetinfoRequestHandler : public BaseRequestHandler
         "  send     Time since last message sent to the peer, in seconds\n"
         "  recv     Time since last message received from the peer, in seconds\n"
         "  txn      Time since last novel transaction received from the peer and accepted into our mempool, in minutes\n"
-        "           \"*\" - whether we relay transactions to this peer (relaytxes is false)\n"
+        "           \".\" - we do not relay transactions to this peer (relaytxes not available as peer connection is still being set up)\n"
+        "           \"*\" - we do not relay transactions to this peer (relaytxes is false)\n"
comments.body:
IMO, it would be worthwhile to use '`.`' to signal we aren't relaying txs (i.e. `relaytxes is false`) and have '`*`' signal the case where the info is unavailable. 

Mainly for two reasons, consistency and intuition. Regarding consistency, `addrp` already uses '`.`' to signal that we aren't relaying addresses (specifically, when `addr_relay_enabled is false`) which is a similar case here, as `relaytxes is false`. Though currently on master, '`*`' is used to show when `relaytxes is false`, it breaks that consistency also, and I'd say '`*`' intuitively seems more like an undetermined/pending state than '`.`'.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -642,7 +643,8 @@ class NetinfoRequestHandler : public BaseRequestHandler
         "  send     Time since last message sent to the peer, in seconds\n"
         "  recv     Time since last message received from the peer, in seconds\n"
         "  txn      Time since last novel transaction received from the peer and accepted into our mempool, in minutes\n"
-        "           \"*\" - whether we relay transactions to this peer (relaytxes is false)\n"
+        "           \".\" - we do not relay transactions to this peer (relaytxes not available as peer connection is still being set up)\n"
+        "           \"*\" - we do not relay transactions to this peer (relaytxes is false)\n"
comments.body: It's a slightly larger change of behavior, but sure -- done.

comments.diff_hunk:


+  latter value is a new, third state since 24.0 returned by the RPC getpeerinfo "relaytxes" field when the peer
comments.body:
(cont'd)

```suggestion
  last value is a new third state since 24.0 returned by the RPC getpeerinfo "relaytxes" field when the peer
```

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,7 @@
+Tools and Utilities
+-------------------
+
+- CLI `-netinfo` now displays 3 different states in the `txn` column (true, false, and not available), as the

@@ -0,0 +1,7 @@
+Tools and Utilities
+-------------------
+
+- CLI `-netinfo` now displays 3 different states in the `txn` column (true, false, and not available), as the
+  latter value is a new, third state since 24.0 returned by the RPC getpeerinfo "relaytxes" field when the peer

@@ -642,7 +643,8 @@ class NetinfoRequestHandler : public BaseRequestHandler
         "  send     Time since last message sent to the peer, in seconds\n"
         "  recv     Time since last message received from the peer, in seconds\n"
         "  txn      Time since last novel transaction received from the peer and accepted into our mempool, in minutes\n"
-        "           \"*\" - we do not relay transactions to this peer (relaytxes is false)\n"
+        "           \".\" - we do not relay transactions to this peer (relaytxes is false)\n"
+        "           \"*\" - we do not relay transactions to this peer (relaytxes not available as peer connection is still being set up)\n"
comments.body: See https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/26457#discussion_r1024158792, I think the third state (N/A) would not be used during connection startup as intended. I confirmed this by adding a sleep at the beginning of `::VERSION `processing in `ProcessMessage` and querying getpeerinfo with this branch - I'd get `relaytxes= false` but the field is included in the response.
